subject: Add boot count into motherboard eeprom and clear command
commitMessage:
Add boot count into motherboard eeprom and clear command

The bmc boot count which was previously stored into
the file /etc/conf/bios.cnt, is now stored into the
motherboard FRU eeprom/sys/bus/i2c/devices/4-0050/eeprom
starting from offset of 4 bytes from 0x1000.

The reading and writing to the FRU eeprom is handled
by using the helper functions.

Added the new IPMI clear command which sets the eeprom
to the default value of ff ff ff ff.

Use of 4 bytes from 0x1000 location to check
if the boot counter is at the max value or at the default
value which server as a header to the boot count.

All corner cases such as invalid command and invalid
command length have been added

Tested:
ipmitool raw 0x34 0x71 0x00 - read current boot count.
ipmitool raw 0x34 0x71 0x01 - increment the boot count by 1.
ipmitool raw 0x34 0x71 0x02 - set the boot_count to all ff which
is its default value of eeprom location where the boot count is
stored.
ipmitool raw 0x34 0x71 0x03 byte1 byte2 byte3 byte4 - set the
boot count to desired value provided by the request parameter.
Reboot,powercyle,flashing bmc - performed to see if the value
retains.

Signed-off-by: Avenash Asai Thambi <avenash.thambi@fii-usa.com>
Change-Id: I99dd5e6ba1d943e558e984d948bd63552cd5278f

Patch Set 7:

I think the sys file interface is copied from phosphor-ipmi-blobs-binarystore.
Also do you need this abstraction for a single ipmi command? Can you just directly do the file operations in the command function?

Patch Set 7:

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> I think the sys file interface is copied from phosphor-ipmi-blobs-binarystore.
> Also do you need this abstraction for a single ipmi command? Can you just directly do the file operations in the command function?

Yes, you are right the sys file interface is copied from phosphor-ipmi-blobs-binarystore. And the reason for the abstraction is for future purpose, to keep it generic so in future if we need to use those functionalities to write and read we can use them.

Patch Set 7:

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> > Patch Set 7:
> > 
> > I think the sys file interface is copied from phosphor-ipmi-blobs-binarystore.
> > Also do you need this abstraction for a single ipmi command? Can you just directly do the file operations in the command function?
> 
> Yes, you are right the sys file interface is copied from phosphor-ipmi-blobs-binarystore. And the reason why it is like that is, to keep it generic so in future if we need to use those functionalities to write and read we can use them. We can use the file operations directly in the command function if that is what is needed.

Not by that package. this change is not using that package. It copies the sys file implementation from that
size is not used anywhere. so the type can be directly passed here.

I think this function can be rewritten. 
Instead of a vector, use uint32_t and this can help with avoiding those logic of creating a vector by pushing and popping.
This logic can be casted to uint32 and operated on.
Commit message should not exceed 72 characters. some of these lines are over the limit.
Since this repo is foxconn-ipmi-oem, we don't need this tag. This is typically used for tagging a sub directory in a repo that has multiple packages or meta-layers.
Should not be present here. Already defined in the other header.
Add "count" in the name to be clear.

This can be just magic/header. Since structure name will have boot_count. the members can be named what it denotes within the structure.
Same for boot_count. It can be just count
Can this be split in to 2 different commands? One for writing explicit value and other for increment? That will simplify the whole logic.
If write and increment are separated, there will be no need to check the request size.
Even when we split the commands, we still have to check the parameter size for the corner cases right ?
It is not INITIAL, the header will be the same always.
close helper function has been created

Move the reqParams.size() validation before the switch cases. 
like 
request size validation block and return on error.
then switch-case for operation.
Took the reqparams out and checked the corner case

This is a common file and can be used by multiple commands. Using a single global file descriptor will cause one command overwriting the other. 

Return the file descriptor when opened and clients need to pass it for every operations.
returned file descriptor and passed it as a parameter to other helper functions

Don't need to mention decimal. 
Just use 0x prefix for hex and default will be considered decimal.
Clear should set the boot count to 0
boot_count_operation should be local to the function
Coding style: leave space after "," in arguments

When boot count is cleared, it means the value should be reset to 0. 
So the header should remain and value should be set to 0.

Having it global will cause issues if any other command uses this function. I think PCIe command will be using file operations too.
I don't think you need to support offset in sysopen. You can just open it and do the actual offset operation in the read and write and pass the correct offsets from the calling function.
follow file format. Use space for indents. Not tabs
follow file format. Use space for indents. Not tabs
follow file format. Use space for indents. Not tabs
Don't need this. Must be included in the offset itself.
This file is similar to the bios function file, so are these headers needed?

I think the HEADER validation and initialization can be brought here. 
Before you enter the switch case, check for the header and if it is invalid, initialize it and return that count. 
It is repetitive in every case.
All the returns in error case does not close the file. Use a variable to store the return value and use a label at the end that closes the file. use goto and jump to that label on error conditions.

This one has been modified in a way where the file is not opened until all the corner cases that lead to error code. In this way we don't need to close the file once error response occurs because the file is not opened at that point in code.

Multiple lines are tab indentation while others are space. 
Use 4 space indents throughout the file.

Should be invalid command. 
Command not available means the command is a valid one but not available in this case. Here it is an invalid command.
No longer called fcntl. can stop the line at "helper functions"
